issue_description:
# DOC Contributing guide: fix formats of links in PR Checklist section

#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation
In the section "Pull Request Checklist", this is how the text appears

```text
A moderate use of type annotations is encouraged but is not mandatory. See [mypy quickstart](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started.html) for an introduction, as well as [pandas contributing documentation]( https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/development/contributing.html#type-hints) for style guidelines. Whether you add type annotation or not:
```

#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

Note:  the links need to be formatted from Markdown to `.rst`

issue_comments.body:
I'm wondering whether we shouldn't remove these instructions about type annotations. See related discussions in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/16705#issuecomment-683477933
CC @rth

Hi @reshamas !
I checked the contributing doc text (on the website as well as the doc source code) for the line you've mentioned and it seems to be absolutely fine...
How should I proceed?

P.S: There is one possible change that can take place-
Adding '__' instead of the existing '_' present at the end of the hyperlink in the code

> I'm wondering whether we shouldn't remove these instructions about type annotations. 

If other maintainers want to as well, I won't argue against it :)

This issue was already addressed a while ago in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/18056 so I'll close.

@reshamas before reporting doc issues, make sure to check the latest docs ;) https://scikit-learn.org/dev/

Hi @NicolasHug 
Does this mean I should look at .html files instead or .rst files?
Or, that I was looking at an old release of the docs?

> Does this mean I should look at .html files instead or .rst files?

I usually look at the html because it makes rendering issues more obvious, and users read the html files, not the rst

> Or, that I was looking at an old release of the docs?

Yes. If you were looking at the rendered docs, you were probaby looking at https://scikit-learn.org/stable/ instead of https://scikit-learn.org/dev

If you were looking at .rst files, the repo was not up to date and it needed a `git pull upstream master`

@NicolasHug Do you think it's worth adding this as a tip to the Contributing docs?
Before opening an issue or submitting PR, check DEV instead of STABLE docs for latest version?

I doubt it will be effective IMHO because the contributing guide is already quite crowded so this would just be buried among a lot of other info. Also this kind of mistake doesn't happen often I think.

(Also, judging by how many PR titles are properly prefixed with `[MRG]` or `[WIP]`, most even don't read the guidelines :( )
